title: The Goldfinch
author: Donna Tartt
description: The author of the classic bestsellers The Secret History and The Little Friend returns with a brilliant, highly anticipated new novel. A young boy in New York City, Theo Decker, miraculously survives an accident that takes the life of his mother. Alone and abandoned by his father, Theo is taken in by a friend's family and struggles to make sense of his new life.

In the years that follow, he becomes entranced by one of the few things that reminds him of his mother: a small, mysteriously captivating painting that ultimately draws Theo into the art underworld. Composed with the skills of a master, The Goldfinch is a haunted odyssey through present-day America, and a drama of almost unbearable acuity and power. It is a story of loss and obsession, survival and self-invention, and the enormous power of art.

Theo's loss is compounded by the absence of his father, and he is tormented by a longing for his mother. He grows up, from a troubled adolescent in a wealthy Park Avenue household to a dissolute young man in the American West, carrying with him the one thing that gives him hope: the painting.

reviews.author: BookLover42
reviews.body: An absolute masterpiece. Tartt weaves an intricate story that kept me captivated for every one of its 771 pages. The character development is extraordinary, and the way she brings the art world to life is nothing short of magical. This is one of those rare books that stays with you long after you've finished reading.

reviews.author: CriticalReader
reviews.body: While the prose is undeniably beautiful and the first half is gripping, the novel loses its way in the middle section set in Las Vegas. The pacing becomes uneven, and some plot points feel unnecessarily drawn out. Still, the ending brings it all together in a satisfying way.

reviews.author: LiteraryExplorer
